title: Composting Bedded Pack Manure with Jeff Endres

tasks.task: Conducting a farm composting workshop and sharing knowledge on composting processes and benefits.
subtasks: Introducing the presenter and their background in sustainable farming practices (family history, agriculture experience, board chair roles).

Exploring the reasons for and benefits of farm-scale composting (reducing volume, concentrating nutrients, pathogen reduction, improved soil health, alternative storage, flexible application timing, reduced groundwater risk).
Detailing the composting process, including ingredient mix (bedding pack manure and separated fiber), windrow construction, turning frequency, temperature monitoring, and moisture management.
Discussing the economic aspects of composting versus traditional manure handling, including cost analysis, fertilizer value, and handling logistics.
Presenting NPK analysis of compost samples, highlighting variable nutrient values based on feedstock composition.
Sharing best practices for managing compost carbon-to-nitrogen ratios, moisture levels, and turning times to optimize decomposition and pathogen kill.
Discussing equipment needs and custom-built solutions for compost turning and handling, including the use of spreaders and spreader modifications.
Outlining challenges and considerations for winter composting, such as moisture management and using sheltered facilities.
Highlighting the benefits of composting for heterogeneous farm fields, redistribution of nutrients, and improving soil health through organic matter addition.
Addressing questions on pathogen removal, groundwater protection, nutrient retention, and the effect on greenhouse gas emissions.

tasks.task: Hosting a Q&A segment to address specific queries regarding composting processes, equipment, economics, and environmental benefits.
